text: welcome to the rotunda in our virtual
Capitol building feel free to look
around and explore our exhibition on how
individual voters elect the next
president come polling day Americans
make their choice for a president and
their running mate then all of the votes
from the state are counted but that
method doesn't take into account the
population of each state and how much
weighting their choice should carry in
the overall national result and that is
where the electoral college vote comes
in the influence an individual state has
is measured by the number of electors
it's allocated and that is tied to the
number of people who live there so a
really popular state like California has
55 electoral votes whereas South Dakota
witnessed population of less than a
million has just three if a candidate
wins a state even by just one vote they
gain all the electoral college votes in
that state if you look oppositely across
the Rotunda you can see that the only
exceptions to the rule are Maine and
Nebraska where the electoral college
votes are split proportionally in total
there are 538 electors across the United
States to gain a majority therefore to
win the election a candidate needs to
win 270 electoral votes and that is the
all-important number to keep in your
mind come election night so votes
secured rest easy for the
president-elect well not exactly
whoever wins the White House in November
will have to work with Congress here in
our virtual Capitol building
that's the Senate and the lower house of
representatives at the moment both
houses are controlled by the Republicans
but with the entire house and 1/3 of the
seats in the Senate up for election both
could change hands so this time
everything is at stake in Washington's
balance of power and of course you can
follow all the twists and turns of the
election here on the BBC
